pageData.text: Soil is a material and natural body that supports numerous ecosystem services critical to life on Earth. Key properties affecting soil’s ability to provide these services are soil <button class='glossary-text'>particle</button> size and distribution, <button class='glossary-text'>organic matter</button> content, and mineral composition. These properties in turn affect more measurable properties, including <button class='glossary-text'>soil texture</button> and color. In this investigation, you will examine soil texture and color in order to identify the soil type and possible mineral content.

Activity 3: Soil Color - 30 minutes

pageData.text: What color is the soil on the moon? From Earth, it looks white or yellowish due to reflected sunlight. Those who have visited the moon report that it is mostly varying shades of grey, lighter in more calcium-rich areas and darker in more iron-rich areas. But, in 1972, geologist Harrison Schmitt, an Apollo 17 Astronaut, discovered patches of orange soil when he disturbed the topmost layer. The color of this soil was surprising. Orange and red soils usually indicate levels of iron oxide, which is formed when iron mixes with oxygen and water. The abundance of iron oxide is why the soil on Mars is red. But the moon was thought to have no oxygen or water, so iron oxide should not be able to form. Only recently have we been able to better understand how this soil may have formed and research is still ongoing to figure out exactly how this rust formation occurs1. It turns out that both oxygen and water can be found in very small amounts on the moon. The oxygen is likely from Earth’s magnetotail, which trails behind Earth as it moves; the water could be coming from multiple sources on the moon. Ice has been found at the poles in shadowed craters and mixed with rocks. It is possible that this water is mixing with the soil when dust impacts the moon to allow for rust formation.

1NASA. (2020, September 2). The Moon is rusting, and researchers want to know why. NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory.
https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/the-moon-is-rusting-and-researchers-want-to-know-why

pageData.desc: The full moon at night as seen from Earth.
pageData.altText: The full moon at night as seen from Earth.

pageData.subTitle: What Is Soil?
pageData.text: Soil provides many services to the earth’s ecosystems (Figure 1). Many of them are obvious, such as supporting plant growth physically and chemically and holding water. Some of the other services are less obvious but include contributions to climate regulation and biodiversity support. How soil provides these functions is determined not only by its composition but also by its physical properties and structure.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: the 6 key ecosystem services of soil: support plant growth, nutrient cycling, preserving biodiversity and habitat, atmospheric and climate regulation, water retention and filtration, and engineering medium
pageData.altText: Figure 1: the 6 key ecosystem services of soil: support plant growth, nutrient cycling, preserving biodiversity and habitat, atmospheric and climate regulation, water retention and filtration, and engineering medium

pageData.text: Soil is both a material and a natural body that can be defined in 3 main ways:

text: Soil is a mixture of minerals, <button class='glossary-text'>organic matter</button> (including living microorganisms), air, and water capable of supporting plant life. Air and water are found in between mineral and organic <button class='glossary-text'>particles</button>, in spaces called <button class='glossary-text'>pores</button>.
A soil is an individual 3-dimensional natural body containing layers of soil (Figure 2), the material as well as plant roots, burrowing organisms, large stones, and even human artifacts.
The soil refers to all of the individual soils around the world, together, and can also be called the pedosphere.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: diagram showing the 3 major horizons of soil: the surface horizon open parenth A close parenth, the subsoil open parenth B close parenth, and the substratum open parenth C close parenth; the organic horizon open parenth O close parenth can either be on the surface or buried
pageData.altText: Figure 2: diagram showing the 3 major horizons of soil: the surface horizon open parenth A close parenth, the subsoil open parenth B close parenth, and the substratum open parenth C close parenth; the organic horizon open parenth O close parenth can either be on the surface or buried

pageData.text: An average soil contains ~45% mineral , ~5% organic particles, and ~50% (Figure 3). Proportions of minerals and vary from soil to soil, whereas within one soil the proportions of air and water change with the weather. Organic matter is defined as dead and decomposing organism tissues along with living microorganisms. Pores or are the spaces between mineral and organic particles where air and water can be found. After a heavy rain, soil pores fill with water, and as they dry, the water drains, gradually letting more air into the soil.

It is the properties of each individual soil, especially the proportions of mineral particle sizes, types of minerals, and proportion of organic matter that most affect soil function, such as nutrient cycling and water retention. These properties in turn arise from soil formation conditions, causing soil properties to vary greatly across the globe due to factors like climate, vegetation, and bedrock type.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: the major components of any soil, including mineral and organic particles, and pore spaces
pageData.altText: Figure 3: the major components of any soil, including mineral and organic particles, and pore spaces

pageData.subTitle: Soil Texture
pageData.text: Arguably the property with the single greatest influence on soil functioning is , or the proportion of different sized mineral particles in soil. Soil textures can be grouped into based on relative proportions of less than 2 mm in size, called fines. Coarse fragments larger than 2 mm are generally excluded, as are organic particles made from dead and decomposing organisms and their tissues, such as leaf litter and wood fragments. The mineral particles that contribute to soil texture are classified based on their size as , , or . Within a particular soil, each of these classes are individually called a .

The particle size of each soil separate influences its <button class='glossary-text'>specific surface area</button> (area per unit mass) and average pore size, which greatly affects plant growth. Surface area affects nutrient retention and flow, whereas pore size affects water retention and flow. The characteristics of each soil separate are quite distinguishable, as are their impacts on soil function.

Sand particles are the largest, ranging from 0.05 to 2 mm in size. Sand particles feel rough and gritty to the touch because our fingers can detect individual grains. They can be jagged or smooth and rounded and are generally rich in weathering-resistant minerals such as quartz and feldspars. Due to their large size, sand particles have a low surface area and large between particles. These large pores allow water to flow through rapidly, and do not hold as much water for plants as smaller pores between other particles.

<button class='glossary-text'>Silt</button> <button class='glossary-text'>particles</button> range from 0.002 to 0.05 mm in size. They feel smooth because these particles are too small to feel individual grains but can be jagged or smooth in shape. Silt is generally comprised of moderately weatherable minerals. The surface area of silt is higher than that of <button class='glossary-text'>sand</button> but lower than <button class='glossary-text'>clay</button> since <button class='glossary-text'>specific surface area</button> increases as particle size decreases. The <button class='glossary-text'>pores</button> in between these medium-sized particles are optimal for retaining water that is available for plants

Clay particles are less than 0.002 mm (<2 μm) in size. Unlike sand and silt, clay particles are very thin and stick together. This makes clay feel sticky to the touch when wet. When dry, clay feels hard and cloddy. Due to the small size of its particles, clay has the highest surface area and smallest pore size, allowing it to retain the most water and nutrients of all of the . However, less of this retained water is available to plants.

Using a <button class='glossary-text'>soil textural triangle</button>, specific percentages of sand, silt and clay can be converted into one of 12 <button class='glossary-text'>textural classes</button> (Figure 4). Each of the 3 axes in the soil triangle corresponds with a different soil separate, and the black arrows indicate the direction in which each separate should be read. Textural class names include combinations of the words sandy, silty, clay, and loam (composed mostly of sand, silt, and a smaller amount of clay). These general classes are grouped according to soil physical behaviors that can be measured using the “feel” method.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: A soil analysis chart displayed as an equilateral triangle, with each angle representing 100% clay, 100% sand, and 100% silt.
pageData.altText: Figure 4: A soil analysis chart displayed as an equilateral triangle, with each angle representing 100% clay, 100% sand, and 100% silt.

pageData.subTitle: Measuring Soil Texture
pageData.text: can be measured using various methods, but in this investigation, you will use two at-home methods: the and the .

The feel method of soil textural analysis relies upon key properties of each : the stickiness of , the smoothness of , and the grittiness of . As the name implies, you must feel the soil to do this method. The first test is to see if the soil will form a ball; clay and silt can do this because clay is sticky and cohesive, and adhesive forces of water are sufficient to hold together small silt . Sand particles will not hold a ball form, as they are not sticky and are too large to be held together in this way. Second, the soil is squeezed or rolled into a ribbon or wire shape to evaluate the amount of clay present. Since clay is the only sticky soil separate, soils with more clay have a high level of plasticity and they can be molded and hold their shape, even when molded into a ribbon and held on end. The more clay the soil has, the longer a ribbon can be made with it, and this affects the last portion of soil name:

text: Ribbon is less than 2.5 cm -> relatively low in clay -> name ends in “loam”
Ribbon is 2.5–5 cm long -> moderate clay content -> name ends in “clay loam”
Ribbon is more than 5 cm long -> high clay content -> name ends in “clay”

pageData.text: Finally, the soil is spread out and felt thoroughly for grittiness and smoothness. A grittier feeling indicates more sand, whereas a smoother feeling indicates more silt. Therefore, soils that feel gritty have “sandy” at the beginning of their textural class names, whereas soils that feel smooth have the term “silty” in their textural class names.

The relies upon the different rates at which differently sized fall through water. The effect of particle size on falling velocity is described by , which states that as particle size increases, settling rate also increases. Therefore, will fall fastest through water, followed by and However, Stoke’s law assumes that all particles are separated from each other and perfectly round, whereas clay particles are normally flat, plate-like, and stuck to each other. These characteristics of clay particles and other clumped particles can cause errors in the results expected by Stoke’s law. Such errors can be minimized with dispersing agents such as household soap. Dispersing agents cause particles to stay apart instead of sticking together, and detergents act as secondary dispersing agents by dissolving sticky organic compounds such as sugars and proteins. In the simplest sedimentation method, the thickness of sand, silt and clay layers that settle is measured to determine their relative proportions, and the results applied to the () to determine soil type.

pageData.question: One method of determining a soil’s texture is to feel a moist sample of it with bare hands. Which of the following sets of adjectives best describes the texture by feel of sand, silt, and clay, respectively?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: When determining soil texture by feel, sand feels gritty, silt feels smooth, and clay feels sticky.

pageData.question: Marsha has 2 soil samples. Soil A holds together when rolled into a ball. Soil B falls apart when rolled into a ball. Which of the following statements about Soils A and B is true?

options.text: Soil A has a higher clay content than Soil B.
Soil A has a higher sand content than Soil B.
Soil A is not as wet as Soil B.
Soil A is a clay soil and Soil B is a loam soil.
Soil A has a lower silt content than Soil B.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Clay is the only sticky soil separate, therefore soils with more clay have a high level of plasticity and they can be molded and hold their shape. Sand particles will not hold a ball form, as they are not sticky and are too large to be held together in this way.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
The feel method of soil textural analysis relies upon key properties of each soil separate: the stickiness of clay, the smoothness of silt, and the grittiness of sand. As the name implies, you must feel the soil to do this method. The first test is to see if the soil will form a ball; clay and silt can do this because clay is sticky and cohesive, and adhesive forces of water are sufficient to hold together small silt particles. Sand particles will not hold a ball form, as they are not sticky and are too large to be held together in this way. Second, the soil is squeezed or rolled into a ribbon or wire shape to evaluate the amount of clay present. Since clay is the only sticky soil separate, soils with more clay have a high level of plasticity and they can be molded and hold their shape, even when molded into a ribbon and held on end. The more clay the soil has, the longer a ribbon can be made with it, and this affects the last portion of soil textural class name:
  • Ribbon is less than 2.5 cm -> relatively low in clay -> name ends in “loam”
  • Ribbon is 2.5–5 cm long -> moderate clay content -> name ends in “clay loam”
  • Ribbon is more than 5 cm long -> high clay content -> name ends in “clay”

pageData.subTitle: Soil Color
pageData.text: Soil color can be used to detect certain colored minerals as well as provide an index of . Some colors can definitively indicate certain minerals. This is the case for ironbearing minerals, which are the only common soil minerals to have red or orange colors. Ironbearing minerals can also be yellow, brown, or on rare occasions, green or black.

It is important to note that while brown to black colors usually indicate organic matter, certain minerals or combinations of minerals can also appear brown or black. For example, manganese oxides and iron sulfides can appear black, as can soils with high concentrations of organic matter. Sometimes iron oxides (minerals with Fe bonded to O or OH), which come in many colors, can mix with each other to appear brown. Goethite, often yellow, can also appear brown and be mistaken for organic matter.

Table 1 shows examples of common colors and Munsell colors for everyday soil minerals and organic matter. The color of some minerals are also dependent on their size; crystal size is given for these minerals.

*When crystal size is missing, it means the mineral is non-crystalline or crystal size is variable. Adapted from NRCS “The Color of Soil”
https://web.archive.org/web/20071027060221/http:/soils.usda.gov/education/resources/k_12/lessons/color/

Since human perception of color is subjective, soil color is measured using the , which assigns a code to each color (Figure 5; see also examples in ). This set of numbers and letters includes the , , and . The hue is the type of color (red, yellow, green), and is denoted by one to two numbers followed by one to two letters. To determine the color, a color plate with examples is used to assign the number code, and the number is then followed by designating letters. For example, a shade of orange is given the number 10 and code YR because yellow and red pigments together make orange. The value is represented by the number immediately following the hue. In this system, value is proportional to lightness: a value of 8, for example, indicates a shade of white, whereas a value of 1 or 2 indicates a shade of black. In terms of value in the red hue, a pink would have a high score (red mixed with white), while a maroon would have a low score (red mixed with black). Lastly, chroma is represented after the value following a forward slash. Chroma indicates the intensity or vividness of color, or how pure the hue is in relationship to its gray content. For example, an emerald and a grape could be both the same green hue and value, but the emerald is much purer in green (higher chroma) while the grape is more gray (lower chroma). Thus, in the Munsell color system, the hue, shade, and purity of a color are represented.

In this investigation, you will determine the <button class='glossary-text'>soil texture</button> and composition of known samples. You will use the <button class='glossary-text'>sedimentation method</button> to visualize different layers in the soil samples, utilize the <button class='glossary-text'>feel method</button> to assess soil texture, and finally utilize the Munsell color system to assess soil color. The results of each of these tests will then be used to determine the composition of unknown soil samples.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Visual representation of the meaning of the representation of the hue, value, and chroma in the Munsell color system
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Visual representation of the meaning of the representation of the hue, value, and chroma in the Munsell color system

A map describing the procedural workflow for activity 1 of this investigation. Before beginning, you will collect a soil sample and prepare the mixed soil sample. In activity 1, you will fill a cup with water. Then, you will mark and label the vials. Next, you will add the designated soil, sodium carbonate, water and dish soap to the vial. Then, you will cover the vial with parafilm and mix the vial contents. Once you have set up all 4 vials, you will let the soil sit for 24 hours. If you cannot see through the supernatant, let the soil sit for an additional 24 hours. Then, you will observe and measure the soil layers. Next, you will observe the samples, calculate the particle size distribution of each layer, and determine the soil texture using the triangle. Then proceed to activity 2.
pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for activity 1 of this investigation. Before beginning, you will collect a soil sample and prepare the mixed soil sample. In activity 1, you will fill a cup with water. Then, you will mark and label the vials. Next, you will add the designated soil, sodium carbonate, water and dish soap to the vial. Then, you will cover the vial with parafilm and mix the vial contents. Once you have set up all 4 vials, you will let the soil sit for 24 hours. If you cannot see through the supernatant, let the soil sit for an additional 24 hours. Then, you will observe and measure the soil layers. Next, you will observe the samples, calculate the particle size distribution of each layer, and determine the soil texture using the triangle. Then proceed to activity 2.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for activities 2 and 3 of this investigation. After completing activity 1, in activity 2, you will measure the mass of the soil and add water to it. Then, you will use the feel method flowchart to identify the soil texture. Next, you will photograph the ribbon formed from the soil. Then, you will use the soil triangle to determine the soil type percentages and record your observations. When you have completed this for all 4 soil types, proceed to activity 3. In activity 3, you will compare the soil color to the Munsell color chart in the app and decide on the matching color. Then, you will record the hue, value, and chroma for the chosen color. Next, you will photograph the sample with the chosen color chip. When you have tested all the soil samples, dry out soil samples X and Z.

Then, you will record the hue, value, and chroma for the chosen color. Next, you will photograph the sample with the chosen color chip. When you have tested all the soil samples, dry out soil samples X and Z.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for the laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).
Sodium carbonate can cause eye irritation. Wash skin thoroughly after handling.

pageData.desc: warning symbol

pageData.text: Safe practices for conducting fieldwork: Never conduct fieldwork on your own, especially in remote areas; always take a responsible partner with you. Prepare and leave a field safety plan, complete with planned survey locations and expected return time, with a responsible party. Wear appropriate clothing (long pants and close-toed shoes are usually best), sunblock, and insect repellant if necessary. Be familiar with the potential hazards in your chosen survey areas. Please review the “Field Work” portion of the Laboratory Safety Manual or your school’s specific safety guidelines for more information. Make sure that you are healthy enough to participate in fieldwork. If in doubt, consult your medical practitioner.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing these activities. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing each activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

Read through the activities.
Obtain all materials.
Clean and sanitize the work area.

Using the 24 oz deli container from the equipment kit, collect approximately 1 cup of soil from about 0–8 cm (0–3 in) below the surface. This sample is the “Collected Soil” sample and will be used in all the activities. Before using the sample, remove excess grasses, roots, and other plant materials, and break up any large clumps.

Note: If you are unsure if a public location is appropriate to collect a sample from, contact your local Parks and Recreation, Fish and Wildlife, State Park, Bureau of Land Management, or National Forest Department.

Note: Before using the sample, remove excess grasses, roots, and other plant materials and break up any large clumps. You may need to spread the soil out flat to find most of the plant residues. If your soil has a substantial amount (>10% or so) of coarse fragments like gravel or plant debris, you can sieve it with a colander or a sieve.

pageData.desc: Figure 6: A metal colander with handles filled with soil containing excess fragments and a metal bowl filled with a smaller amount of soil that has been strained
pageData.altText: Figure 6: A metal colander with handles filled with soil containing excess fragments and a metal bowl filled with a smaller amount of soil that has been strained

pageData.text: You will make a mixed soil containing Soil Sample Z and your Collected Soil to use as a comparison in Activity 1. Obtain a plastic bag. Label the bag “Mixed”.
Place the weigh boat on the scale. Tare the scale so that it reads zero. Then weigh out portions of each soil sample.

text: Weigh approximately 6 g of the Collected Soil. Pour it in the Mixed bag.
Weigh approximately 3 g of Soil Sample Z.
Pour it in the Mixed bag.
Thoroughly mix the sample.

pageData.text: Make sure each soil sample from the materials kit set is also thoroughly mixed. You can do this with your hands or with a spoon.
Soil Sample Y is an inhalation danger.  Wear a protective face mask when weighing Soil Sample Y.  Once sample Y is wet, it is no longer an inhalation danger.

pageData.text: In Activity 1, you will prepare soil samples in vials with water and allow the different types of <button class='glossary-text'>particles</button> to separate over 24 hours. You will then observe and measure the soil layers and calculate the particle distribution of each layer to determine the <button class='glossary-text'>soil texture</button> of the sample.

pages.title:
A
 Determination of Soil Texture Using Sedimentation Method (18 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Determination of Soil Texture Using Sedimentation Method (18 steps)

pageData.text: Fill the cup up with tap water.
Obtain the vials and label them “Sample X”, “Sample Z”, “Mixed”, and “Collected Soil”.
Note: Put the label toward the top of the vial.
Using the ruler, mark 3 cm and 7.5 cm heights on each vial.
Use a funnel and fill each vial up to 3 cm with its designated soil sample.
Note: Gently tap the vial; if the soil settles below the line, add more soil until the vial is filled to the line again.
Use the digital scale and a weigh boat to measure 1.0 g of sodium carbonate (Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>). Add 1.0 g of (Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>) to each soil sample.
Slowly pour water from the filled cup into each vial. When you start to get close to the 7.5 cm line, use the dropper pipette and finish filling each vial to the 7.5 cm line with water.
Add 1 small drop of dish or hand soap to each vial.
Cut the square of Parafilm® into 8 equal pieces. You will use 2 of the pieces to cover each vial. Save the other 4 for use in Activity 2.
Note: You have an extra square of Parafilm® in case you need to repeat this step or any other step.
Cover each vial with a cut square of Parafilm<sup>®</sup>.
Note: : Parafilm® is flexible and can be stretched to fit over the top of each vial. It will work best when the outside of the vial is dry.
Each vial needs to be thoroughly mixed.

text: Put your gloved thumb or the palm of your hand over the top of the of the Parafilm<sup>®</sup> of the vial labeled “Sample X”

pageData.text: Hold the vial horizontally between your hands (Figure 7) and gently tap against your other palm and shake for at least one minute. This shaking process ensures that <button class='glossary-text'>particles</button> disperse (separate) from each other.
pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.desc: Figure 7: person wearing a lab apron and gloves shaking a vial horizontally and gently tapping the bottom of the vial
pageData.altText: Figure 7: person wearing a lab apron and gloves shaking a vial horizontally and gently tapping the bottom of the vial

text: Make sure no soil remains at the bottom of the vial.

pageData.text: If the sample bubbles or soil remains at the bottom of the vial, continue shaking and inverting for at least another minute.
pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Note: If after 2 minutes the soil continues to bubble, the soil may be acidic. You will need to add another 1.0 gram of Na2 CO3 to the vial and repeat Steps a–d. For extremely acidic soil samples, additional increments of 1.0 g of Na2 CO3 may be necessary.

text: Repeat Steps a–d for the other samples.

pageData.text: Make sure the vials are covered with Parafilm® and allow them to settle for at least 24 hours. Check your vials after approximately 40 seconds to observe settled and then again after approximately 2 hours to observe settled . Record your observations in the observation column of Data Table 1.
Note: Put the rack in a safe place where they will not be knocked over or otherwise tampered with by pets or children

After 24 hours, check the liquid in each vial. The liquid should be clear enough to see light through. The liquid maybe be yellow, brown, or look like tea. If the liquid in the soil sample is cloudy or has a milky appearance, allow the sample to settle for another 24 hours.
pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Once the supernatant (liquid above the soil) is clear enough to see light through, hold each vial against a white piece of paper.

Observe the different layers that have formed in each vial. Mark the location of each layer in each soil sample. You may need to hold the sample up to a bright light to distinguish the layers. If you can’t distinguish the layers. Repeat Steps 10–12 in Activity 1.
Take a picture of each sample against the white sheet of paper. Ensure that the particle layers are visible in the photo. Turn on your camera’s flash or take the picture in sunlight to see clearly.
pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Use the ruler to measure (cm) the depth of the sand (bottom layer), silt (middle layer), and layer (top layer) in the soil samples. Figure 8 shows how soil typically settles. Figure 9 shows how a collected sample may look. Record the in Data Table 1.
Note: Not all soil samples have all of the distinguishable layers.

pageData.desc: Figure 8: diagram showing particles settling; sand is shown at the bottom, and clay is at the top; organic matter open parenth humus close parenth is shown floating on top of the water. A silt layer is formed between the clay and sand layers
pageData.altText: Figure 8: diagram showing particles settling; sand is shown at the bottom, and clay is at the top; organic matter open parenth humus close parenth is shown floating on top of the water. A silt layer is formed between the clay and sand layers

pageData.desc: Figure 9: A beaker containing a collected soil sample open parenth after settling for 24 hours close parenth showing marks for clay, silt, fine sand, and coarse sand
pageData.altText: Figure 9: A beaker containing a collected soil sample open parenth after settling for 24 hours close parenth showing marks for clay, silt, fine sand, and coarse sand

pageData.text: Calculate the particle size distribution of each sample by dividing the thickness of each layer by the total depth of the soil, then multiply that value by 100. Record the percentages of the primary particles (clay, silt, and sand) in the Collected Soil Sample in Data Table 1.
Use the () to determine the of each sample, as measured after soil settling, and record this in Data Table 1.
In Activity 2, you will use the Soil Texture Feel Method Flow Chart to classify moist soil by feel.

You will be evaluating each soil sample (“Sample X”, “Sample Y”, “Sample Z”, “Collected Soil”, and “”) with the using the Soil Texture Feel Method Flow Chart, which should be printed to keep your device clean as you work. Use the digital scale and weigh boat and weigh 20–30 g of sand. Pour the sand into your hand. The sand sample will act as a “Control”.
Soil Sample Y is an inhalation danger. Wear a protective face mask when weighing Soil Sample Y. Once sample Y is wet, it is no longer an inhalation danger.
pageData.desc: warning symbol
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.text: With the pipette or a spray bottle, slowly add water until all the <button class='glossary-text'>particles</button> appear wetted.
Note: If your soil is very dry, you may want to start with a few pipettes full or ~3 sprays of water. Once the soil starts to get wet, you can slowly add one drop or one small spray at a time.

text:
Most soils are at the proper consistency when plastic and mobile, like moist putty. In the case of sand, you’ll want the soil to reach a consistency similar to a sandcastle.
Note: To determine using feel method, you will need to take off your gloves. This enables you to feel the rough sand particles and distinguish them from smooth particles.

If the soil remains in a ball (Figure 10) when it is gently tossed and caught again, then proceed to Step 3. If the soil does not remain in a ball when gently tossed and it is still dry, add more water one drop at a time.

pageData.desc: Figure 10: person wearing a lap apron and gloves with both palms facing up; in one hand is a ball of moist soil that appears to be the consistency of moist putty
pageData.altText: Figure 10: person wearing a lap apron and gloves with both palms facing up; in one hand is a ball of moist soil that appears to be the consistency of moist putty

text: If the soil is too wet, add dry soil to soak up the excess water, and repeat Step 2.

If the soil is not too wet or too dry, and no amount of adjusting the amount of water or soil makes the soil stay in a ball, its textural classification is “Sand”. Try this with the labeled “Sand” sample to see what a sand soil feels like. Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.

pageData.text: Place the ball of soil between thumb and forefinger, gently pushing the soil with your thumb, working it forward into a ribbon.

text: Form a ribbon of uniform thickness and width.

pageData.text: Allow the ribbon to emerge and extend over your forefinger and break from its own weight. Take a picture of the ribbon formation, or lack of ribbon formation. If possible, include your hand in the photo, showing the ribbon before it breaks.
pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Note: You can put your phone or camera in a plastic bag to protect it from the soil samples.

1. If the soil will not form into a ribbon, it is classified as “Loamy Sand”, and the texture is classified as “Course”. Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.
  2. If the soil will not form a ribbon, feels extremely smooth, and it is not gritty at all, it is classified as “Silt”. Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.

text: If the ribbon breaks before it is 1” long, pinch off a small piece and get it excessively wet and rub with your forefinger.

pageData.text:
1. Does the soil feel very gritty?
    1. If yes, the soil is classified as “Sandy Loam”, and the texture is “Moderately Coarse”. Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.
  2. Does the soil feel very smooth?
    1. If yes, the soil is classified as “Silt Loam”, and the texture is “Medium”. Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.
  3. If the soil is neither predominately gritty or smooth, it is classified as “Loam”, and the texture is “Medium”. Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.

text: Does the soil make a medium ribbon 1” to 2” long before breaking?

pageData.text:
1. Pinch off a small piece and get it excessively wet and rub with your forefinger.
  2. Does the soil feel very gritty?
    1. If yes, the soil is classified as “Sandy Loam”, and the texture is “Moderately Coarse”. Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.
  3. Does the soil feel very smooth?
    1. If yes, the soil is classified as “Silty Clay Loam”, and the texture is “Fine.” Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.
  4. If the soil is neither predominately gritty or smooth, it is classified as “Clay Loam”, and the texture is “Fine.” Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.

text: Does the soil make a strong ribbon 2” or longer before breaking?

pageData.text:
1. Pinch off a small piece and get it excessively wet and rub with your forefinger.
  2. Does the soil feel very gritty?
    1. If yes, the soil is classified as “Sandy Clay”, and the texture is “Moderately Coarse.” Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.
  3. Does the soil feel very smooth?
    1. If yes, the soil is classified as “Silty Clay”, and the texture is “Fine.” Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.
  4. If the soil is neither predominately gritty or smooth, it is classified as “Clay” and the texture is “Fine.” Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.
Use the soil triangle () to determine the approximate percentage of sand, silt, and clay ranges. Record the results in Data Table 2.
Set aside approximately one teaspoon of soil to use in Activity 3.
Repeat Steps 1–5 for each soil sample.
In Activity 3, you will compare the soil to the colors in the Munsell color chart app to determine the color of each sample.
Use saved soil samples from Activity 2.
Hold Soil Sample X up to the Munsell color chart in the Munsell Color app.
In the Munsell Color app, if given the option, use the “constant hue plane” tab, which is the default.
Hues are letters (R, YR, Y) with numbers in front of them. To switch to different hues (on different pages) in the Munsell color app:

1. In the iPhone app, click “Move” at the bottom; then, choose among the hue letters, and then the hue numbers.
  2. In the Android app, toggle among the pages using the right and left arrows towards the top (stay in the “Constant Hue Plane” tab at the very top left to do this).
Click on the color you think matches to expand it.
After clicking the color that best matches your soil, the correctly formatted Munsell color will appear at the bottom of the screen.
Record the , and in the format HH HH V/C in Data Table 2; for example, 10 YR 5/4.

Take a photo showing the Collected Soil Sample next to the color chip(s) you chose from the Munsell book. Each soil must be touching each color chip or rest on top of it; place your device showing the color chip in a plastic bag to keep it clean.
pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Repeat Steps 2–8 for the remaining soil samples.

You will need to dry Soil Samples X and Z and put them back into their bags once they are dry and for use in future investigations. Do not dry Sample Y; when this soil sample is dry, it can be an irritant.
pageData.desc: warning symbol
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.text: Label a piece of cardboard or a sheet of newspaper with the name of the soil. If using newspaper, place it on a paper towel. Spread out the soil on the cardboard or newspaper and allow it to dry. Once the soil sample is dry, put it back into the bag. You may need to use the sample again in future investigations.

text: Wash the equipment with soap and water.
Place Soil Sample Y in the household trash.
Sanitize the work space and wash your hands thoroughly.

pageData.title: Thank you
pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

text: For each soil, compare and contrast the soil texture results you obtained via the sedimentation method in Activity 1 (Data Table 1) versus via the feel method in Activity 2 (Data Table 2). Which soils, if any, did you get similar results for?  Which soils, if any, did you get different results for? Specify which soil separates were different in your answer (ex: “my texture by feel estimate had more sand and less silt than my sedimentation method result”).
What might explain differences in results between methods? Address sources of error for both methods in your answer.
Stoke’s law explains how soil particles settle in water.  This law also applies to situations in nature. Can you give an example?

You do a soil particle size analysis by dispersing 50 g of dry soil in a cylinder containing 1L of water plus dispersing agents and recorded the following hydrometer readings: 40 seconds = 41 g/L; 2 hr = 9 g/L. In this method, it is assumed that all sand settles within 40 s, and all silt settles within 2 h. It’s also assumed that all clay stays in suspension throughout the method. What is the percentage sand, silt, and clay, and the textural class? Hint: The hydrometer method is a sedimentation method like the one you used, but units are reported in g/L instead of cm. These units cancel out during the calculation.

pageData.text: % sand =
% silt =
% clay =
Textural class (use soil textural triangle):

text: Which one of the 12 soil textural classes from the textural triangle is not included in the flowchart for determining soil texture by feel? How would you recognize such a soil textural class if you were handed an example?

pageData.content: Printable Soil Texture Feel Method Flow Chart
Figure 1. The role of soil in ecosystems
pageData.altText: Figure 1: the 6 key ecosystem services of soil: support plant growth, nutrient cycling, preserving biodiversity and habitat, atmospheric and climate regulation, water retention and filtration, and engineering medium

Figure 2: diagram showing the 3 major horizons of soil: the surface horizon open parenth A close parenth, the subsoil open parenth B close parenth, and the substratum open parenth C close parenth; the organic horizon open parenth O close parenth can either be on the surface or buried
Figure 3: the major components of any soil, including mineral and organic particles, and pore spaces
Figure 4: A soil analysis chart displayed as an equilateral triangle, with each angle representing 100% clay, 100% sand, and 100% silt.

pageData.content: How to Use a Soil Analysis Chart
Table 1. Munsell colors of common minerals
pageData.title: Table 1.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Visual representation of the meaning of the representation of the hue, value, and chroma in the Munsell color system

A map describing the procedural workflow for activity 1 of this investigation. Before beginning, you will collect a soil sample and prepare the mixed soil sample. In activity 1, you will fill a cup with water. Then, you will mark and label the vials. Next, you will add the designated soil, sodium carbonate, water and dish soap to the vial. Then, you will cover the vial with parafilm and mix the vial contents. Once you have set up all 4 vials, you will let the soil sit for 24 hours. If you cannot see through the supernatant, let the soil sit for an additional 24 hours. Then, you will observe and measure the soil layers. Next, you will observe the samples, calculate the particle size distribution of each layer, and determine the soil texture using the triangle. Then proceed to activity 2.

A map describing the procedural workflow for activities 2 and 3 of this investigation. After completing activity 1, in activity 2, you will measure the mass of the soil and add water to it. Then, you will use the feel method flowchart to identify the soil texture. Next, you will photograph the ribbon formed from the soil. Then, you will use the soil triangle to determine the soil type percentages and record your observations. When you have completed this for all 4 soil types, proceed to activity 3. In activity 3, you will compare the soil color to the Munsell color chart in the app and decide on the matching color. Then, you will record the hue, value, and chroma for the chosen color. Next, you will photograph the sample with the chosen color chip. When you have tested all the soil samples, dry out soil samples X and Z.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: A metal colander with handles filled with soil containing excess fragments and a metal bowl filled with a smaller amount of soil that has been strained

Figure 8: diagram showing particles settling; sand is shown at the bottom, and clay is at the top; organic matter open parenth humus close parenth is shown floating on top of the water. A silt layer is formed between the clay and sand layers
Figure 9: A beaker containing a collected soil sample open parenth after settling for 24 hours close parenth showing marks for clay, silt, fine sand, and coarse sand
Figure 10: person wearing a lap apron and gloves with both palms facing up; in one hand is a ball of moist soil that appears to be the consistency of moist putty

data.title: Chroma
data.content: The intensity or vividness of a color

data.title: Clay
data.content: A soil separate that is less than 0.002 mm in size

data.title: Feel method
data.content: A method of soil textural analysis that relies on physically feeling the key properties of each soil separate

data.title: Hue
data.content: The type of color; is denoted by one or two numbers, followed by one or two letters on the Munsell color system

data.title: Munsell color system
data.content: A system of measuring soil color by assigning a code to each color

data.title: Organic matter
data.content: Matter comprised of dead and decomposing organism tissues along with living microorganisms

data.title: Particle
data.content: A tiny piece of sediment, either organic or inorganic, found in the soil

data.title: Pore
data.content: The space between mineral and organic particles where air and water can be found; also called a pore space

data.title: Sand
data.content: A soil separate ranging from 0.05 to 2 mm in size

data.title: Sedimentation method
data.content: A method of soil textural analysis that relies on the different rates at which differently sized particles fall through water

data.title: Silt
data.content: A soil separate ranging from 0.002 to 0.05 mm in size

data.title: Soil separate
data.content: Each class of mineral particle that contributes to soil texture

data.title: Soil textural triangle
data.content: A commonly used visual representation of the possible soil type combinations based on soil particle size

data.title: Soil texture
data.content: The proportion of different sized mineral particles in soil

data.title: Stoke's law
data.content: States that as particle size increases, the settling rate increases; for example, sand will fall faster than silt

data.title: Textural class
data.content: One of 12 types of soil texture based on the relative proportions of particles less than 2 mm in size

data.title: Value
data.content: The number right after hue in the Munsell color system; the value is proportional to lightness, where 8 indicates a shade of white and 1 or 2 indicates shades of black
